questions.question: What is double spending in the context of blockchain?

answers.a: Sending the same cryptocurrency to two different recipients simultaneously.
answers.c: The process of creating new blocks in a blockchain.
answers.d: Storing cryptocurrency in a hardware wallet.

questions.question: In a blockchain, which entity is responsible for verifying and confirming transactions?
Which consensus mechanism makes it computationally expensive to attempt double spending in a blockchain?
How does a centralized system typically prevent double spending?

answers.a: By relying on a trusted third party to validate transactions.
answers.b: By distributing transaction records across multiple nodes.
answers.c: By requiring miners to solve complex puzzles.

questions.question: What feature of blockchain ensures that transactions cannot be altered once confirmed?
Why does double spending not occur in a properly functioning blockchain?

answers.a: Because transactions are only processed once a day.
answers.b: Because the network agrees on a single transaction history.
answers.c: Because users are limited to one transaction at a time.
answers.d: Because all transactions are stored offline.
